awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Advancing Innovation in Bio-Design through Reality-Based Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, research in human-computer interaction (HCI) has generated a broad range of interaction styles that move beyond the desktop into new physical and social contexts.  Key areas of innovation in this respect are tabletop, tangible, and multi-touch user interfaces.  These interaction styles leverage users' existing knowledge and skills of interaction with the real, non-digital world; thus, they are often referred to as reality-based interfaces.  Such interfaces offer a natural, intuitive, and often collaborative form of interaction that reduces the mental effort required to learn and operate a computational system.  While these advances in HCI have been successfully applied to a broad range of application domains, little research has been devoted to investigating reality-based interaction in the context of scientific discovery.  The PI argues that it is particularly important to study reality-based interaction in this context, where reducing users' mental workloads and supporting collaborative work could potentially lead to exciting scientific advances.  For example, in a preliminary study of the workflow and computational tools employed by synthetic biologists, the PI found that members of this research community often experience difficulties in specifying, comparing, documenting, and sharing information - interactions that have previously been shown as critical for scientific discovery.  She further observed that the limitations of current computational tools pose barriers for collaboration, information flow, and exploration.  This lack of appropriate computational tools coupled with the inherent complexity of biological systems has limited progress to date, despite the enormous potential of synthetic biology to solve problems such as low-cost drug development and alternative energy production.  In this project, the PI will investigate how reality based interfaces may be able to advance innovation in biological design.  To address this question, she will develop and evaluate a suite of reality-based interfaces that support the design and assembly of novel biological systems, and which she expects will promote collaborative, effective, and safe workflow, facilitate exploration of alternative solutions, and reduce the mental workload associated with accessing and relating large amounts of information.

Broader Impacts:   Project outcomes will include: design, implementation, and evaluation of a suite of reality-based interfaces for synthetic biologists; a set of design requirements for developing future such systems; a methodology for evaluating the efficacy of computer-supported cooperative work of scientists; novel techniques for fluid interaction with heterogeneous computational devices of different scale; and a set of design considerations and a participatory design process for supporting scientific discovery.  The PI will train three female undergraduate researchers per year, who will be an integral part of her research team and will participate in an international science competition.  The project will impact computing and science courses at the PI's institution (a women's college) and at collaborating institutions.  In addition, this research will serve as a highly visible "magnet" project that attracts undergraduate and high-school students' attention to computer science research through outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past two decades, Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) research has generated a broad range of interaction styles that move beyond the desktop into new physical and social contexts. Key areas of innovation in this respect are tabletop, tangible, and multi-touch user interfaces. While these advances in HCI have been successfully applied to a broad range of application domains, little research has been devoted to investigating emerging human-computer interaction styles in the context of scientific discovery and learning.  

This project applied innovation in human-computer interaction to enhance discovery and learning in the emerging field of synthetic biology. We developed and evaluated a suite of novel interfaces that support the design and assembly of biological systems by: 1) promoting collaborative, effective, and safe workflow; (2) facilitating exploration of alternative solutions; and (3) reducing the mental workload associated with accessing and relating large amounts of information.

This suite of interfaces includes two bioinformatics applications, which support collaborative bio­design of complex constructs: MoClo Planner – a multi-touch user interface that streamlines the design and specification of biological constructs using new visual representations  of the the Modular Cloning (MoClo) DNA assembly method; and Eugenie a tangible user interface for browsing large biological data sets and for constructing complex queries for combinatorial bio-design with active tangible tokens and an interactive tabletop. Evaluating these interfaces with novice synthetic biologists shed light on the benefits of multi­touch and tangible interaction for exploring large and complex data sets. We also developed a preliminary prototype of a wearable system, which utilizes gestural interaction to provide novice scientists with contextual real-time support in the wet laboratory. This application shows promise towards regularizing manual bio­design and assembly scientific protocols, which could result in safer and more productive processes.

The project also focused on creating novel interactive exhibits that utilize advances in human-computer interaction to enable non­experts to engage in biological design activities while learning core principles of synthetic biology.

Creating an interactive platform for exploring bio­design brings into direct conflict the goals of design and tinkering (tangible, responsive, and open ended) and the confounders of biology (invisible, unintuitive, slow, and prescriptive). Though using authentic tangible labware is desired, virtual augmentation is necessary to bring the time and size scales into the range of a play session. Our goal was to investigate how tangible and gestural interaction can bridge time and size scales to facilitate learning of core concepts of synthetic biology in informal learning environments. To accomplish this goal, we designed and implemented two interactive museum exhibits for synthetic biology: SynFlo and BacPack. SynFlo utilizes active tangible tokens, programmable physical objects with integrated display, sensing, or actuation technologies, which were embedded in authentic lab ware to allow visitors to experience a playful and collaborative bio­design activity. BacPack applied tabletop and tangible interaction to allow museum visitors to take on the role of a scientist to engineer digital bacteria that can help explorers on scientific missions in extreme environments such as Mars. Both exhibits were presented and evaluated at the Tech Museum of Innovation in San Jose, CA. and in the Boston Museum of Science. Overall, more than 1000 museum visitors interacted with these exhibits.  

During the five project years, more than 24 undergraduate students (22 female), and 3 post­bac students (all women) were involved in the project. 16 of these students co­authored scientific papers and abstracts with the PI. 24 students participated in the prestigious International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) contest, winning 3 gold medals.

In summary, this project advanced the theory and practice of bio­design automation contributing computational tools for the specification, design, and assembly of synthetic biological systems. We also demonstrated the potential benefits of using wearable interfaces to regularize the manner in which humans execute protocols. The project also has had an impact on informal learning of STEM concepts and interaction design for children by creating new interactive exhibits for biological sciences that bridge the size and time scales of biology to enable learning through an interactive play session.
